On Wed, Oct 01, 2003 at 09:32:01AM -0400, jalgermissen@... wrote:
> I have some questions regarding REST's definition[1] of resource:
> 
> REST (re-)defines resource to be an abstraction not only of a)
> information
> resources (e.g. Web pages) but also of a) services and b) abstract
> concepts.
> While I see a clear reason for the neccessity of b) for REST to be an
> architecture suitable for distributed systems I cannot see a reason for
> c). IMHO,
> abstract concepts are not within the realm of distributed systems but
> are
> subject to knowledge representation/information management (in other
> words:
> subject to possible applications of the architectural style, but not
> part
> of the architecture itself).
> 
> Can anyone explain to me, why REST actually re-defines 'resource' to
> include
> c) ?

Every thing (two words 8-) is a resource.  c) is automatically included
by this definition, and to remove it would be arbitrary, and would
lessen the power of the Web.

> The second question I have is related to the question what the
> semantics of a resource are.  Roy's dissertation says:
> 
> "REST accomplishes this by defining a resource to be the
>  semantics of what the author intends to identify, rather
>  than the value corresponding to those semantics at the
>  time the reference is created."
> 
> To me this seems to contradict the idea of authorities defining the
> semantics of resources.

No, it's just that the document returned via GET doesn't have to be
100% unambiguous about what the URI identifies (and I suggest that it
couldn't be if it wanted to, but that's another topic for another day
8-).

For example, a URI that returned a picture of a clock in my house could
be used to identify the following resources;

- the current time
- that particular clock
- the largest clock in my house
- a JPG image of a clock
- an object located 6.5' above the floor in my kitchen

From an observer's POV, the URI could identify any of those if I'm
only ever returning an image from my webcam pointed at that clock.

>  What is the precise meaning of 'author' here?
> Author of a 'document' that uses a particular URI or the author that
> somhow 'brings into being' a particular resource?

Any use of the URI can contribute to its meaning.  Using the clock
example, if a bunch of people used that URI to identify "the current
time", and then my clock breaks and I decide not to fix it (I'm using
it to identify "that particular clock"), then there is, in effect, an
expectation on me to change what it identifies to what most people
think it identifies.  It's up to me whether or not I want to do that,
of course.

A great example is the SOAP 1.1 URI at W3C; http://www.w3.org/TR/SOAP/ .
The URI should be able to be used as the identifier for "the latest
W3C version of SOAP", but so many people were using it to explicitly
refer to SOAP 1.1, rather than "SOAP in general", that the W3C made an
explicit decision not to redirect that URI to SOAP 1.2 once it went Rec.
FWIW, they did redirect for HTML; http://www.w3.org/TR/html

Mark.
